>>61889273
i didnt care too for so long but now im starting to care fml its just so unfair.. Not only are they extremely hot they also get to make 20MM a year for years scamming with bikini pics on OF

its just so unfair i feel like crying

61893415

nigga are you stupid, hot girls have always had ez mode, any girl with looks + little brains can hustle money like crazy. 61893631
>>61889354
I met a girl who was a friend of a friend of mine at a party when I was younger and she literally handed me a business card with her OF address on it. I didn't realize what it was at first but the second I read it I blurted out "What the fuck is wrong with you?" without thinking and she got super offended. I'm pretty sure I was the first person she handed it to that actually said anything negative about it by the way she reacted, which is very bizarre to me. It's kind of crazy how common this shit is.

61893680
>>61889270
Like everything in the world of money being born a woman was a gamble
You just lost it

item.title: Tried selling my silver today >spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area >p… — 22 replies — 88.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Tried selling my silver today >spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area >p…

Open thread • Replies: 22 • Updated: 2026-02-25 05:49 UTC

OP

Tried selling my silver today

>spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area
>pawn broker says they only pay 90% of spot price, including a 12% processing fee
>IRS also collects 28% in taxes
>pawn broker laughs and tells me the next town over 100 miles away has pawn shop
>might aswell try
>halfway there, spending another 20 bucks on gas, my back left tire blew out
>didnt have a spare
>call towing company which ended up costing hundreds of dollars
>had to buy two tires just to not mess up wheel alignment

And i thought crypto fees were abhorrent

Early replies (first 3)

61893318
>>61893298
You fell for the holding physical meme. I am PM ETFs and can sell for spot in click of a button

61893323
>>61893298
>>61893166
Samefag. Cope and seethe.

61893429
>>61893298
You don’t sell physical unless you actually need the money to buy something else. It’s not an investment. It’s insurance

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61893472
>>61893429
it's an investment that has paid off more than stocks tho

61893477
>>61893318
no you can't lol. silver ETFs are like $10 below spot

61893485
the 2026 panda coin is pretty cute. might get some
>in before it's fake cuz chinks hurfdurf

61893516
>>61893298
you weren't supposed to want to ever sell it
did you get the latest COVID vaccine booster?

61893951
>>61893298
Youre supposed to sell to a real person. Fuck institutions, fees, and the (IRS)

61893968
>>61893298
>Be me
>European
>200 dealers in a 200km radius
>Go to dealer with 3% spread for buying and selling
>Sell for 99% of spot as long as it's anything remotely tradeable like a Panda
>Don't pay taxes (like most Europeans below the Main river)
Wtf is your problem? They'll even pick it up if you ask.

61893992
>>61893298
what a dumb boomer LARP. just use the internet to sell your silver like you use it to tell lies on a mongolian basket weaving board, retard.

61894003
>>61893298

>Tried selling my silver today
First mistake.

>spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area
Have you tried not living in Alaska?
>pawn broker says they only pay 90% of spot price, including a 12% processing fee
So they pay 2% over spot...Nice
>IRS also collects 28% in taxes
Common misconception that precious metals are taxed at 28%. The reality is that you owe tax according to your income bracket which means that if you make around $60k per year you only owe 12% on precious metals capital gains. If you make $600k+ per year then yes you will owe 28%.
>halfway there, spending another 20 bucks on gas, my back left tire blew out.
What does this have to do with silver?
>didnt have a spare
You make $600k per year and you can't afford a spare tire???

61894008
>>61893516
SILVERMARINES
NEVER SELL
ONLY ROCKS
FOREVER
NO FOOD
NO HOUSE
NO CAR
JUST SILVER

61894081
>>61893298
>sold the bottom
>struggles with simple tasks
Classic frog poster.

61894082
>>61894008
this but unironically

61894105
>>61894003
It’s an Israeli making up a story, or a dumb faggot white retard nigger making up a story.

61896846
>>61893298

61897078
>>61893298

*yawn*
Got anything new?

61899403
>>61893298

61899440

My company's VDI has been down for the entire day from morning to night. Apparently started since the day before in Asia. Nobody can login and we probably lost millions in dollars.
Its still not fixed.
Tfw all our IT got outsourced to jeets in kolkata
Not going to say my company name so i dont get subpoenad to death but its pharmaceutical

>>61898325

The best part is none of us could contact IT since we couldnt login and our VP had to call kolkata lmao. I looked at the stocks and nothing happened so i guess no one is aware. What a disaster.

Supposedly at 18 it's limited to educational expenses and buying a house until they reach 30(????). Which is good because that would be really annoying if your kid got $100k and bought a gaming laptop and a base model Ford mustang

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61896616
Tesla is in the tech industry, not in the car industry. You'd have to be a double digit IQ redditor to not understand this.

61896618
>>61896337
The chinese manufacturers haven't taken over 90% of european market share yet just because they are taxed to shit. The european car companies are fucking dead and I say this as someone from a family that's only ever owned european cars.
Anyways. Elon antics aside, Tesla is an american company that makes cars primarily for Americans, and that type of business has never been successful in Europe. Even Ford who ran a European branch in England making cars like the Fiesta and Focus has been losing traction for a while now and other brands like Chevy which used to be somewhat common 20 years ago are completely gone now.
I don't think it will impact the stock price a lot though, since that's pricing tesla as a space robot company that's going to colonize mars using catgirls, not a car company.

>>61896612

That seems interesting. Repsol and Fed Ex are recent members and all new members are required to have a use case they are working on, and supply chains and energy tracking seem good fits for DLTs. Will take a looooong time, though, of course.
I really don't know if crypto has another pump-n-dump fad like NFTs, DeFi, Dapps etc left in it. It really might just be the long wait for mainstream institutional adoption (another reason why I rate Hedera over most others).

61895162
>>61891947
why would banks use rlusd or xrpl as a bridge currency when they can just atomically swap stablecoins? Theres no nostro-vostro in crypto, underlying assets can be sold anywhere instantly at any time, even automatically via smartcontracts or even put into liquidity pools for any overhead

61896947
>>61895162
XRP is natively used on the XRP in cross minted asset swaps at a fraction of the cost and speed of off or cross ledger settlement with basically bottomless on demand liquidity so that low volume corridors don't get blown out and weird continuous markets don't need to be developed for an efficient universal system. XRP also has none of the risk inherent in smart contracts, is completely counterparty-less and using ILP the whole thing can scale to literally trillions of tps with fees paid in any currency, capable of micropayment batching. XRP is less risky, has no counterparty or contract risk and scales liquidity regardless of the currency pair instantly with no need to establish liquidity between the currency pairs let alone specific issuer walled garden tokens (USDC vs. USDT vs. RLUSD vs. every other national etc. stablecoin) and costs less and finalizes faster. Literally every single reason they would be considering is better done this way, with a few frictions as technically possible with current DLT and zero middlemen unless they choose to have them, completely decentralized, being able to atomic swap on ILP through their own chosen structure.

item.title: The War with Iran — 21 replies — 10.6/hr
item.content:encoded:
The War with Iran

Open thread • Replies: 21 • Updated: 2026-02-25 03:52 UTC

OP

A geopolitical risk premium is priced-in to all parts of this market right now.

We see a 3 different potential scenarios:

1. US makes deal with Iran: Stocks rise, commodities fall

2. US does "one-time" strike with Iran: Brief volatility which ends with stocks rising, commodities falling

3. US enters prolonged war with Iran: Stocks fall, commodities rise

Our positions win in 2 of the 3 scenarios outlined above, which we believe are more likely than #3.

If the US truly is setting up for a long war with Iran, then this would be highly bearish for equities, bullish for crude and gold.

Why don't we think this is the case?

President Trump wants $2/gallon gas and wants to be the "Peace President." None of these objectives are obtained in a prolonged war with Iran, particularly with mid-term elections on the horizon.

That is our current mindset on how we are approaching this market.

Early replies (first 3)

61895853
I also have a club for those interested in the stock market, where I publish all paid premium content, as shown in the attached photo. I will save you time and hundreds of dollars on subscriptions, which you will get practically for free.
